awd_titl_txt: ABI Innovation:   Robotics-inspired modeling and design of proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of California San Francisco is awarded grant advance approaches that can capture and engineer structural changes in proteins. This is important both to make designs more accurate and to engineer functions that require structural changes. Computational protein design has enormous potential to transform many areas of science and engineering by creating proteins with useful functions: new enzymes to build biological synthesis pathways that can produce important chemicals and fuels; selective signaling molecules that can process biological information; and new protein materials with sophisticated functions mimicking their biological counterparts. This research seeks to develop computational methods to ultimately make such complex protein functions designable.  Specifically, project will produce (i) methods to model changes in enzymatic specificity and improve the design of active sites; (ii) methods to model and design signaling proteins that act as switches; and (iii) benchmarked and documented protocols available to biologists and biological engineers.

Recent design successes that created novel enzymes, protein-protein interactions, and nanomaterials are spurring both academic and industrial interest in proteins with modified, new, and useful functions. Combined with a considerable expansion of technological capabilities (such as large-scale de novo construction and characterization of biological "parts"), there will be an increasing need for more predictive design methods, such as the ones developed here, to create proteins with new and more complex activities. Applications span broad areas including computational and structural biology, metabolic engineering, and synthetic and cellular biology. The new methods developed under this grant will be used in graduate courses and team projects in molecular engineering designed to foster collaboration between students from the biological and physical/engineering sciences, as well as in undergraduate and high-school research activities at UCSF. Improved computational methods will be disseminated broadly as source code via the Rosetta suite of computational tools (www.rosettacommons.org) and via easily accessible web applications.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, SAN FRANCISCO, THE

por.por_cntn:
Designed proteins with new functions have tremendous potential to advance many areas of science and engineering. They provide new ways to study fundamental biological processes and help to solve important problems for the bio-economy by creating new biological activities. Potential applications include new enzymes and biological synthesis pathways for molecules that are otherwise too expensive to produce, or robust sensors and signaling systems that can detect specific inputs and generate a precise response. Over the last decade, there have been significant advances in the computer-aided design of novel functional proteins. However, there are also significant scientific challenges impeding more rapid progress in the field.

The intellectual merit of this research lies in overcoming a key limitation of design: Computational design changes protein sequences to engineer new functions, but allowed only minimal structural adjustments. This approximation is understandable when considering computational tractability, but surprising conceptually, because structural changes are key to many functions. We developed and validated tractable solutions to the problem of accurately modeling protein structural adjustments that occur in proteins. We found that these new methods make design more accurate and useful, because even relatively small structural changes can have a significant effect on function. In a second method advance, we addressed the problem of modeling larger conformational changes that are often critical to more complex functions such as the action of protein switches and molecular machines. Borrowing concepts from the field of robotics, we demonstrated considerable improvements in our ability to predict protein conformations and conformational changes with atom-level accuracy. We found that the same mathematics that can control the motions of a robot arm can be used to predict “mechanically accessible” conformations in proteins. This opens exciting avenues to “reshape” proteins for new functions and towards more challenging practical applications of design.

The broader impacts of our work lie in enabling methodologies for protein modeling and design that are now widely used in academia and industry, and training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers including members of groups underrepresented in science and engineering. We have integrated research and education through the development of multiple courses. To make our methods broadly accessible, we disseminated them as source code in the Rosetta program that is free for academic users and licensed by companies, and via web resources that provided several thousands of modeling predictions to other researchers. Our methods are used in applications of considerable biological and biotechnological importance, such as the modulation of protein-protein interactions involved in key cellular functions, and development of protein therapeutics and industrial enzymes with improved selectivities and activities. 

 


Last Modified: 04/15/2016
Modified by: Tanja Kortemme
